bestBHT.bht: Jesus, having arrived near the areas of Bethphage and Bethany, villages east of Jerusalem and situated on the further side of Mount Olivet, sent two of his disciples ahead to fetch a donkey, laying the foundation for the triumphal entry. Bethphage, meaning house of figs, and Bethany were positioned between Mount Olivet and Jerusalem, allowing Jesus to draw near to the city as he reached this spot. This occurrence took place on the afternoon of Friday, the 8th of Nisan, and it is likely that the two disciples sent were Peter and John.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: of figs," a village which with Bethany lay along the further
side of Mount Olivet, east of Jerusalem.
Philip Schaff: Luke 19:29. And when he had thus spoken, etc. On the afternoon of Friday, the 8th of Nisan. He could reach the neighborhood of Bethany before sundown.
Archibald T. Robertson: Unto Bethphage and Bethany (εις Βηθφαγη κα Βηθανια). Both indeclinable forms of the Hebrew or Aramaic names.
In the Greek it is just a matter of accent (circumflex or acute). Olivet is correct in Acts 1:12.
See on Matthew 21:1; Mark 11:1 for details.
John Gill: He was come nigh to Bethphage and Bethany; two tracts of land which reached from Mount Olivet to Jerusalem; so that when he was there, he was nigh unto the city.
The Mount of Olives...has its name from the great number of olive trees that grew upon it.
He sent two of his disciples; their names are not mentioned...but it is very probable they were Peter and John.
John Wesley: He drew nigh to the place where the borders of Bethphage and Bethany met, which was at the foot of the mount of Olives. Matthew 21:1; Mark 11:1.

bhtAttempts.bht: Jesus, having arrived near the areas of Bethphage and Bethany, villages east of Jerusalem and situated on the further side of Mount Olivet, sent two of his disciples ahead to fetch a donkey, laying the foundation for the triumphal entry. Bethphage, meaning house of figs, and Bethany were positioned between Mount Olivet and Jerusalem, allowing Jesus to draw near to the city as he reached this spot. This occurrence took place on the afternoon of Friday, the 8th of Nisan, and it is likely that the two disciples sent were Peter and John.

Jesus, having arrived near Bethphage and Bethany, villages east of Jerusalem on the further side of Mount Olivet, sent two disciples ahead to fetch a donkey, signifying the start of the triumphal entry. Bethphage, meaning house of figs, and Bethany were situated between Mount Olivet and Jerusalem, allowing Jesus to draw near to the city at this point. This event transpired on the afternoon of Friday, the 8th of Nisan, with the two disciples likely being Peter and John.

Jesus, having thus spoken, approached the vicinity of Bethphage and Bethany, which lay on the other side of Mount Olivet and east of Jerusalem. The two disciples sent by Jesus were likely Peter and John. This encounter, marking the start of the triumphal entry, took place on the afternoon of Friday, the 8th of Nisan. Bethphage, meaning house of figs, and Bethany were positioned between Mount Olivet and Jerusalem, allowing Jesus to draw near to the city when he reached this spot.

Jesus, having reached the vicinity of Bethphage and Bethany, two villages on the other side of Mount Olivet and east of Jerusalem, sent two disciples, likely Peter and John, to fetch a donkey as he prepared for the triumphal entry. This significant event occurred on the afternoon of Friday, the 8th of Nisan. By approaching this area, Jesus brought himself closer to the city, with Bethphage and Bethany situated between Mount Olivet and Jerusalem.

Jesus, having reached the vicinity of Bethphage and Bethany, two villages east of Jerusalem on the other side of Mount Olivet, sent two disciples, likely Peter and John, to fetch a donkey as he prepared for the triumphal entry. This important event took place on the afternoon of Friday, the 8th of Nisan. By approaching this area, Jesus drew nearer to the city, with Bethphage and Bethany positioned between Mount Olivet and Jerusalem.
